This review contains no spoilers.
With a newly acquired and unique future-predicting diary function attached to their cellphones, twelve people spread all over the city get involved in a battle royale to death organized by the current decaying god, in which the winner will become the new god of this world. And so our main character (who happens to be one of the twelve), an ordinary teenager shut-in named Amano Yukiteru, begins his journey accompanied by a mysterious female classmate that seems to know a lot about him. Which one of the Future Diary owners will rise victorious in this bloody thriller where toying with fateis nothing but child's play?


Most synopsis for Mirai Nikki (The Future Diary in english) fail to be clear enough in depicting how amazing its possibilities were in terms of plot. What we get instead is an averagely entertaining show that is best watched with your brain turned off because its flaws are just too hard to overlook. The story, while apparently engaging at first, quickly devolves into nonsense that conveniently spawns one plot point after another. Even the whole constitution of the show (Cellphones that foresee the future and even your own death with some anticipation, while also getting you instantly killed if someone happens to destroy yours) is too far fetched and weak on it's own.


The main character is a loner with zero redeeming qualities who is afraid of everything and the female lead, Gasai Yuno, is an annoying and sick murderer (that somehow possesses top notch assassin skills despite the fact that she's in school) who is pathologically attached to the main character. Oh she's also another Diary owner. While I understand that any normal person would be afraid in these circumstances, it is no excuse to have such an unlikable and WEAK male lead. It deserves to be mentioned, however, the fact that the main character does a 180° later on in the series, over the course of 1 episode or so, which adds to the overall hilarity.


The rest of the cast (the other 10 and some random characters) are hard to describe. They are mostly stereotypical characters with a unique trait or two, some border so much on the ridiculousness that it really becomes hard to take seriously in the context of this show, not to mention that most are obviously discarded as the show advances due to the nature of the plot. While some are sort of interesting (and certainly better than the main two) they are not enough to save the character aspect of Mirai Nikki.


Sound and animation are solid. Special mention to the first opening because it fits the mood and initial tone perfectly, definitely one of the best I've seen. The rest of OPs and EDs were alright, just like the voice acting and soundtrack. Animation was fluid, I have no complaints on that matter either.


But anyway, it is a widely known fact that sound and art are not enough to save an anime. 


So fast forward to needless fan service, decisions and plot devices that lack any logic whatsoever, plot holes, ineffective comedy and EVEN the inclusion of homosexuality; Mirai Nikki simply fails to deliver the strong storyline that it seemed to have at first glance. That's not to say that MN epically fails in every aspect though... the action scenes despite being brainless and devoid of any realism / logic can still be entertaining, the female lead's twisted behavior can be amusing at times (generally when she's not being annoying as hell) and the sound and art are good. Kinda sad that those are all the positive things I've got to say about Mirai Nikki.


So onto the detailed analysis:


General: 

Atmosphere 7/10 --- Nothing stellar, I guess it's hard to build the proper mood for a battle royale filled with whiny teens for the most part. 

Characters  3/10 --- Disappointing and obnoxious. Secondary characters aren't that much better.

Story development & ending 3/10 --- Weak and inconsistent. Despite being a free-for-all, at no point it stops being an episodic battle of the main characters against every single of the other 10. Also plot holes galore.


Technical:

Art 7/10 --- Good, no complaints.

Soundtrack 9/10 --- Background music I don't know, but the OPs and EDs were great (mainly the first OP)

Voice acting 7/10 --- Annoying, but that's how the characters were supposed to behave, and they did a good job at that.


Personal:

Priority (How eager I was to watch the next episode) 6/10 --- Caught my interest sometimes, not gonna lie.

Memorability 4/10 --- I didn't care much when it ended, I didn't care much when I heard about the OVA release. Forgettable.


Final score:

5/10 --- Mediocre


In closing, I can see why some people enjoyed Mirai Nikki, but for some reason I just couldn't bring myself to put up with the glaring plot holes and lack of logic present in almost every point of the show (I can somehow do that for other animes though). The characters and story pacing obviously didn't help much with that, either. Mirai Nikki is an entertaining anime if you are willing to turn your brain off at all the flaws it has and still manage to enjoy it, it has a powerful synopsis and it sure showed potential but in the end, like it happens many times, the execution was poorly done. 


Mirai Nikki is certainly not for kids! The themes it touches can be disturbing and the content itself is a little too explicit. I'd rate it for 16 y/o and higher.


This was my first review, I hope you enjoyed it!

Future Diary (Mirai Nikki) Review
What… a… trip… 
Those were my final words as I finished watching Mirai Nikki 
Disclosure: Future Diary was the third anime (the other two being Ouran High School and Death Note) I had watched after the Dragon Ball, Yu Yu Hakusho phase of where I didn’t know those shows were anime. So, I had to start off my reviews with one of the very first animes I watched. I will try to minimize any spoilers possible! Strictly my opinion on the matter and what I consider a good/bad anime based on my preferences. My scores will be based on a .5scale just to make it easier.


MAL Synopsis: Lonely high school student, Yukiteru Amano, spends his days writing a diary on his cellphone, while conversing with his two seemingly imaginary friends Deus Ex Machina, who is the god of time and space, and Murmur, the god's servant. Revealing himself to be an actual entity, Deus grants Yukiteru a "Random Diary," which shows highly descriptive entries based on the future and forces him into a bloody battle royale with 11 other holders of similarly powerful future diaries.  With the last person standing designated as the new god of time and space, Yukiteru must find and kill the other 11 in order to survive. He reluctantly teams up with his obsessive stalker Yuno Gasai (who also possesses such a diary), and she takes it upon herself to ensure his safety. But there's more to the girl than meets the eye, as she might have other plans for her unrequited love...


MAL Score: 7.86



Ill construct my review based on my views of what a psychological/thriller anime should have (especially one in this setting): 


{Intro}: There are 2 different intros across the span of the 26 episodes of Mirai Nikki. The first track which spans across episodes 2-14 is called “Kuusou Mesorogiwi” and fits the visuals pleasingly well. It has this intense, dramatic feel to it which compliments the anime well. Now, “Dead END” sounded like trash to me. I’m going to keep it 100, it sounded like they were off key while trying to sing in English. The visuals were cool though. 


{Visual/Animation}: For the most part I enjoyed the vibrant colors combined with the dull colors that were displayed throughout the series. The animation was… eh. It was ok for the most part. Fighting scenes were neatly done. I am not one with the complete knowledge of animation so I just saw it as par animation (nothing impressive, nothing utterly ridiculous either). 


{Characters}: Ok, this is where it gets interesting! There’s a cast of 12 contestants 2 of which are the main focus of the story (for the most part). Then there’s 2 other characters but they are used as the overseer’s in this plot. The first contestant is Yukitero Amano (Yukiiiiii) who is an observational and anti social young dude that stole the heart of none other than Yuno Gasai (waifu gone wild). Yuno is the second contestant, who literally protects Yuki from all harm like an obsessive girlfriend should. She pretty much would take care of the dirty work if it meant that Yuki would stay safe. They go through an interesting relationship which appealed to me in this plots context. Then we have the other 10 contestants that (without saying too much) were interesting characters that ranged from considerably “good” to “bad” people. All of the characters have their own distinct look. Everyone with “their own reasons to become the new God”. What I was displeased about was that not every character actually mentioned their reason for winning (even if they did it to just survive). Like, c’mon my guy, tell me why this dudes out here trying to murder someone… what’s his/her goal for being this omnipotent being? Some were done pretty well, others none at all, and that was a bummer. Then we look at the omnipotent beings themselves: Deus Ex Machina (aka Deus) and Murmur. Murmur has some personality and is quite adorable until the end starts nearing. Deus is simply just a bland character on the verge of death. My only issue with Deus’ personality is that he claimed he had fun watching the battle royale he created but you never see him laugh or giggle when someone gets completely murdered. If you’re enjoying it, at least show it my man. We get a quick look at Yuki’s mom, but… who cares? She was a filler character to continue the story. She did want Yuki to pipe Yuno so I guess she was cool. For those who care, my favorite characters had to have been the Seventh Diary User and the Ninth Diary User. 


{Plot}: Hehe there’s plenty of plot if you know what I’m saying! Especially past the midway mark. The actual plot is split into two parts, one being the general battle royale storyline and the other is the “hidden” mystery of the story. The plot isn’t entirely unique but there are many segments which differentiate it from other survival stories. The story did catch me by surprise for the most part. Not in terms of the battle royale but instead the mystery behind it. There are some plot holes which didn’t and still don’t make too much sense to me. For the most part it was a minor inconvenience but it didn’t take away from the beauty of the total project. There is one issue that did bother me with the whole plot and that is because of the arrangements of the fights. Without saying too much, it could’ve been less generic. 


{Sound}: The sounds always seemed to match the mood that the anime was trying to portray. There was intense, louder music during fight scenes, smooth instrumental when something was discovered, and eccentric music when it was a happier scene (which rarely happened). Can't really pick out any moment where the music didn’t fit the scene. 


{Enjoyment}: To make this short and sweet, I really enjoyed Mirai Nikki. I didn’t get completely hooked like I did on anime’s such as: Haikyuu! and Tokyo Ghoul (S1), but it came very close to it. The anime is daring and hectic so it causes excitement every episode while you’re still trying to figure out what’s going to happen in the near future. I would catch myself with my eyes glued to my screen, sitting with my legs bent up like L from Death Note. This was one of the most exciting anime’s that spanned across a span of 26 episodes. 



{Final thoughts}: This shit was awesome! It has a complex story but a fun one to accompany. Characters were unique and had a certain development throughout the story. Music was doooope. I know the anime might seem overhyped since it is a fan favourite (because of Yuno Gasai) but I do genuinely believe it is a really good anime. Not amazing, not a masterpiece. Simply a really good anime. I’d give it a fresh tomato (Rotten Tomatoes reference) and I’d recommend that you watch it if you’re ever in the mood to watch some wild fights in a battle royale with a pretty alluring story and a bipolar girl with pink hair. 


Hope you enjoyed reading my review on Mirai Nikki!

First ever review, be nice. ^_^
This anime moved me emotionally, forcing me onto the edge of my seat at least once every episode. Mix that with unique characters and you have Mirai Nikki.
Whether you want cute or creepy, funny or violent, sad or happy. You'll find all of it in this amazing show.
From the first fifteen minutes of the first episode I knew this show was going to be absolutely fantastic. It had me biting my nails and gritting my teeth, eager to watch the next episode as soon as one finished. 
The characters had vivid backgrounds and have a very real feeling to them.Some of them you want to hug whereas some of them you want to throw off of a building. Some of them both, some of them your opinions of them change throughout the show. \n\n
Unique introductions to the characters which forced you to feel every emotion from sad to angry. A very interesting, and psychological anime with some creepy and cute aspects, loveable and hateable characters and major plot twists happening, Mirai Nikki will leave you in anticipation and begging for the next episode to start.\n\n
Future Diary mixes in nearly every possible genre and manages to pull it off fantastically. A perfect ten out of ten. :3 ♥

Let me tell you all a little tale about a girl who wanted to save the boy she loved from a game of kill or be killed. 12 go in but only one comes out alive. Sound familiar? Yup, because it has been done before. Behold, Mirai Nikki also known as The Future Diary, The Hunger Games of the anime world. 
Now now, I know that is isn't the same as The Hunger Games since a) it came out before The Hunger Games, b) it isn't set in a apocalyptic world with a dome and crazy people with weird hair, and c) if you winthe game you become God and not a infamous person everyone hates. Plus, only one can win. Not two. So let us begin this review with a question, hm?


Why?


Story: 5/10


Easily becoming a overused plotline, this anime is twisted together with different themes, styles, and many many plot holes. I became confused fast on what was going on because well...there was no building of the plot. They literally just threw us into the cage with the lion saying "good luck!" and away we went with an up and down and up and down plot structure. I got sick fast with the roller coaster movement. Now, why cell phones? I get it, it's the 21st century, but did they really have to use cell phones to create a message of "this can be you if you continue to stare at your cell phone instead of going outside and doing whatever"? It's different, but the message of them using it wasn't necessary at the slightest. Plus adding the twist of "guess what, your cell phone was selected out of a million others to go into a killing battle to the death," kind of made me jump back and feel sorry for the characters. The romance part was a little overdone. It was strange the see a woman protecting her man though, its usually the other way around. So that was a nice change for once. But the emotion being used in contrast to everything else didn't fit. And this will be explained in the "art".


Art: 5/10


Another example of a style of art I wasn't particularly fond of. Different colour hair, eyes, school girl uniforms, the typical anime art. Like who designed these characters? To fit the story I felt like they could've gone a darker direction with the design of the characters and background. They seemed to bright of a shade. I get they were trying to mix things up and confuse us with a plot twist, but those plot twist still should match what is happening. Still, for a bright coloured anime, they did use the blood and gore well. I was happy to see this anime live up to the rating's reputation. 


Sound: 6/10


"Is it wrong, to love popcorn and tea. Tea. Biscuits, biscuits, fuck this tea.....Steak Fries." This is the first thing I hear every time I watch the first OP. *slow clap* great choice in song. Great choice. Yeah...no. The beginning song used a psychotic beat to get us 'hyped' for the episode. Yes, they did well to established this. They used perfect amounts of darkness in the animation and song to lead up to...yeah, nothing what I was expected. Why doesn't these openings match with the episodes! They probably should've put in a less darker opening so they wouldn't lead us into something disappointing. 


The voice acting wasn't all too bad. Even the english dubbed was pretty alright. They did match the character's personality well, even Yuno's VA was very well done. I am impressed! 


Character: 3/10


Yuno...the Queen of the Yandere. I think this character inspired the Yandere video game simulator. Either way this girl has serious mental issues. You can tell from the beginning this girl is messed and at first glance you'll think "oh she has multiple personality disorder" but...does she really? She's a big mystery and an overachiever at that. I would feel sorry for the guy who has to date her. Talk about getting no sleep at all. 



Which brings us to contestant number one: Yukiteru Amano! Also known as the guy who got thrown into a cage with a lion thanks to his 'imaginary friends'. More like having schizophrenia. This guy is living on the boarders of reality and imaginary. But still I feel sorry for him being thrown into a battle he probably never wanted to become a part of. 


Minene Uryuu: the only character I actually liked in this entire show. You want to know who's the bad ass in this show, it's her. She's probably the only one who shows that yes, this show is gory and dark and will become a living hell. She's not afraid of anything. She's not afraid of death. She's not afraid of killing. She's not afraid of nothing...except loosing. Yes...I think she's the only sane person in the entire anime. 


Enjoyment/Overall: 3/10


Decent anime, but yeah...up to you if you want to watch it or not. This was a strange anime for me. But am I going to stop you...probably not. I got bored from this anime...but it was a short one so I just fought my way through it I guess. Everyone has their own opinion on it though. Heck, this is one of my best friend's favourites, and here I am giving it a low ranking. Sorry, but this anime was just...not enough and too much at the same time. 


This is a Dead End for this anime. I give it a 47% on the kill scale.

Story-6/10
Gasai Yuno: Don't you know? I really, really, really love you to death, Yukkii.
Although it takes a while to unravel, the romance in Mirai Nikki ends up being very poignant. Up until the last few episodes, the real story of Gasai Yuno remains somewhat of a mystery. Although this method of using hidden information will keep you curious as to what’s going on, the romance will unfortunately come across as very childish and forced. This very difficult to care about (and very much one sided) ‘love’ continues for the majority of the anime until finally, the secret of Yuno is revealed. When this happens, allof those issues with the romance are pretty much solved and the final few episodes end up featuring some incredibly powerful and emotional scenes. After seeing Mirai Nikki’s obvious skill in delivering this drama, it just seemed a shame to have such a standard and immature build up to the climax. 


Sadly, the supposed main story of a survival game ends up just being a plot device for the romance. The dramatic story of Yuno and Yukiteru requires very specific conditions. Thus, the main plotline will decide to change radically and suddenly just to fit these conditions. Most of the time, these ‘plot twists’ have absolutely no reasoning behind them; they just happen. Although this obviously benefits the romance, the survival game itself ultimately becomes a total mess. By the end, even main characters start to defy the laws of physics simply so the ideal circumstances for Yuno and Yukiteru are created. If the main focus was always the romance, was there really any point in having something so complicated to confuse things? 


Art-6/10


The artwork in Mirai Nikki was passable but rather confusing. The artwork never stood out as one of the strengths of the anime. The backgrounds and city views were pretty standard. The beauty behind any aspect of the show was also weak. Where the artwork really succeeded was with the intense/ dark scenes. There was always this juxtaposition with using an innocent design in a sinister way, and while Yuno herself best epitomises this, certain scenes in the anime were also equally as successful. In terms of character design, I was never sure how serious to take Mirai Nikki. On one hand you have a determined, and mischievous looking terrorist, on the other hand you have an oversized, female Oompa Loompa… Wat? I never felt decided on how serious to take Mirai Nikki in the first place, but things like that are completely out of place. 


Sound-9/10


The soundtrack in Mirai Nikki was superb. The show has do deal with a great number of contrasting themes; Yuki may be sitting down with his family one moment and the next, Yuno will be going completely nuts killing everyone. The soundtrack was able to use some really successful OSTs to smoothen this transition. There was also a basic language between the tracks, for example using the same melody but using different instruments to set different moods. Where the sound and art really come into their own is with the OP’s and ending songs, all of which were marvellous. They do a great job of setting the mood in a creative way. Here are a few tracks which best set the mood of Mirai Nikki; ‘Kūsō Mythology’ (the first OP), ‘Blood teller’, and of course the stunning OST (whose name I cannot find),* just type in* ‘volume 2- Track 5 Mirai Nikki’. 


Characters-7/10


Mirai Nikki showed some great potential in terms of characters. The main character, Yuno, was both able to grasp my attention (because of the underlying mystery) and consistently hold it because of her unexpected and completely barmy actions (very much like the show itself). It is always great to see a character that can instantly set you in the mood for that particular show. Other characters like Uryuu Minene also have a strong sense of individuality and were able to entertain through their own decision making that didn’t revolve around benefiting the story.   


Whilst the shows designers clearly had some skill, they rarely used it. The supporting cast was weak. In a survival game with a main character (i.e. the obvious future winner), other characters just seem to exist to develop that main character, then die in an entertaining manner. What was really off-putting was that in Mirai Nikki, even the characters themselves seemed to know this and would do some of the most illogical things just so Yuno/ Yukiteru could benefit. Even Yuki was at it when the story of Yuno needed saving! The rest of the cast ended up being fleshed out by the standard array of stereotypical archetypes which was especially disappointing. 


Enjoyment- 9/10


Mirai Nikki definitely did entertain. There was plenty of drama, action and mystery to satisfy. What I found particularly successful was that each show would both develop the story and provide some light hearted entertainment. As a result, there weren’t any over complicated story explanations, nor was there too much booby touching to frustrate me. Admittedly, the most entertaining aspect of the show was indeed Yuno. It was good fun to just simply watch her mind work and see her in action. The only thing holding back my enjoyment was the fact that I wore my thinking hat very securely on my head. Mirai Nikki, for better or for worse, does require you to put this to the side…


Overall-710


As much as you will enjoy it, Mirai Nikki has its fair share of flaws. For example the undeniable focus on Yuno, which resulted in the discarding or radical modification of different aspects of the story when needed. Whether I recommend watching Mirai Nikki, I would say yes. Just don’t expect a masterpiece. Go in instead with the expectation of a good ol’ bit of entertainment.

If I were a complete novice to anime and someone introduced me to this show, I would be appalled and mark anime off as nothing more than a gore infested whore house of the art industry, because the show comes equipped with more than a few classic anime cliche's that, when kept apart, are rather appealing, but when thrust together, are a shameful mess on the industry. Mirai Nikki holds serious parallels to Sword Art Online for me: both shows have a wicked concept they are based on, but both are destroyed by pacing and modern anime conventions. In the case of Mirai Nikki, theshounen-y 'villian of the week' feel, disturbing rather than pleasant fan service moments, and a total lack of any character development or compelling theming really drown out the positive aspects of the show. But while someone could watch SAO for their first anime and at the very least come away with the idea of anime as having the ability to be both artistically beautiful and imaginative, walking away from Mirai Nikki would at best leave confusion as to if the Japanese were mentally sane. To those who say Mirai Nikki would never be someones first anime, the insane hype for this show would like to say otherwise. Sure, its not many an otaku's first lover, but coming from personal experience, Mirai Nikki was indeed just about my second. And while it does not reach One Piece level stardom, the cult following this show has attained exists as its sole proprietor, like harpies singing beautiful praises from there corpse infested caverns to those unaware of the term yandere and its implications. 


Not at all to say that in any way do I dislike gore, ecchi, severed limbs, the psychological genre, sociopathic protagonists, games of death, or even yandere (or any such dere for that matter). Individually I actually not only can tolerate them but enjoy about everything I just listed. So what could be my issue with Future Diary, an anime chockfull of all of these things and more? It single handedly created its own species of dere for darn's sake! But that is where the line is drawn; you either love Future Diary to death, or like me, you recognize it as a disjointed mess. Herein lies my issue with Future Diary. Somehow, someway, it has become a series that is held up as one of the best things we have to offer to the rest of the world when it comes to animation. Because while the following of SAO has at least come to realize the series is majorly flawed (speaking solely for its first season), judging by the very diverse reviews it receives on this very website, Future Diary still manages to hold a number of 8s, 9s, and 10s within its review section, consistently. And while I'm not saying people can't enjoy whatever they want to enjoy, I'm startled by the amount of people who feel so strongly about this show. Because in my opinion, it's shameful garbage, and here's why:


Strike 1: The synopsis sounds bad-ass, right? Twelve people with diaries on their cell phones that can see into the future use them in order to fight to the death to become the next god. This show sounds immediately up my alley, psychological genre to boot. But a more accurate genre for this is far and away shounen, as instead of moving the focus between characters, chronicling everyone's individual attempts and motivations for becoming god, or any sort of intelligent set-ups and traps made with the use of the Future Diaries, we are instead subject to a whiny, useless protagonist that has nothing going for him besides that fact that, for no reason at all, everyone is going after him. And when I say everyone, I very much mean everyone just stands in a line to wait to get a whack at the first Diary user. Episodes are made up of instances where they introduce a character, said character attempts to kill Yuki, and Yuno does all the dirty work in the process of saving him before the episode is over, without said character having any effect on the entire rest of the cast. 


The Future Diaries tend to only be used in a very immediate fashion, ie characters only whip them out when they are about to die, with only one or two actually using their Diaries before they are in a life or death situation, and I can tell you Yuki and Yuno are not those people (unless Yuno is literally attempting to stalk Yuki). Instead the diaries tend to serve much more as plot progression than devices that could potentially change fate, and even their properties and abilities manage to simply fluctuate with whatever issue has arisen for the characters in trouble, keeping a very consistent level of dues ex machina always present that, more than anything, only manages to detract any sense of real threat from the show. I failed to ever worry about the characters of Yuki or Yuno, not only because I already failed to have an emotional connection to them, but also because I never truly wondered about the outcome of the death game. Yuki holds such a very strong main-character immunity that even as weak and whiny as he was, I never worried about him. Yuno would save him, or Akise would save him, or Eye-patch would save him, or someone would kill themselves so he'd live, or the entire rules of the game would shift just in order to give a reason for Yuki to be saved. So Future Diary is not about the Future Diaries, or the entire death game, and wondering who would become god. Future Diary is really just about the characters, and boy-  


Strike 2: You can read a different review if you want to hear about how much a frustratingly weak character Yuki is, but I'm in full agreement that he is the least compelling of any character on the show, and while he does at one point grow out of his baby phase, it comes in the form of such a complete 180 in character that it's even worse than before, because he becomes equally as psycho as Yuno.


After about episode 5 you begin to realize a few things. One being that the characters of this show choose to make about the worst, most illogical decisions possible. For example: How come literally everyone immediately goes after Yuki after he lives just one time? Literally no battle is shown that is between someone that does not involve Yuki in some form or fashion. Two: How come, whenever anyone else gets a DEAD END, they just sort of give up, when right from the very beginning it is shown that you can evade any such end? I'm talking specifically about instances like the eye ball guy, who I honestly believed to be a compelling character up to the point ***minor spoilers*** of his killing himself, at which point began the very rapid downhill slide for the show. *spoiler end* Three: How come no one actually reads their Future Diary!? I'm serious that there were at least three different instances where someone would look at their Future Diary, read whatever the last text was, and respond immediately to that, without even checking whatever the rest of the thing said, which many times had already recorded their failure. I watched the show dubbed, so I don't know how it went down subbed, but the text messages were handily translated in English for us as well, and so many times were there in which Yuki woud freak out over something written without pausing for a moment to read the rest of his diary that confirmed how useless whatever he was about to do was. Whether this is a production glitch or something done on purpose is irrelevant; it only manages to make them look like total morons.


The second is that these characters do not serve as emotional platforms for us to become invested in, but are really simply back-story infused canon-fodder for Yuno to chop to pieces. If you wanted to see something that included multiple characters with ridiculously sad back stories, go watch Angel Beats! or something along those lines, because here, the writers just decided to think of the most messed up as possible scenarios for their characters while not at all addressing what their motives are for the Future Diary in the first place, besides ruling the world. Nearly no character says what they would do if they did come in possession of the Future Diary, and even the ones who do say nothing more involved than world domination. Many characters are straight-up jokes, or stupid stereotypes, like the four year old child, or the oddly rotund day-care worker. What good would come to them for becoming the Master of the Universe? Of course it's a cool concept, but its not like anyone is rooting for them or anything. 


Outside the primary diary users exists a number of other static support characters, nearly all in some way related to Yuki, such as his posse of friends who tend to be the only logical persons in the entire show, and his parents, who range from overly relaxed to overtly greedy. The only person I can name to have anything even remotely close to character development would be Minene  (eye-patch), and the only character I honestly enjoyed having screen time for was Akise, since he tended to be the voice of reason that went regularly unheeded by Yuki. If we're all being realistic here, Akise should have been the main character of this show. He is the only person remotely close to deserving the powers of the Future Diary, and who would have used them intelligently. Many issues I had with the overall production of the show would have been lost if he had taken the center stage, even if he fails to have any compelling backstory or motivations either, because he at least would have the ability go never seeing Yuno again if he had the choice. 


Strike 3: Really, the entirety of Future Diary is based off of Yuki and Yuno's strenuous relationship, capitalized by the fact there are multiple episodes where all they do is go dress shopping or the entire abduction arc that manages to have nothing to do with the rest of the diary users. When it’s broken down, I do not understand the appeal of Yuno and Yuki together. Yuno is not maybe but totally, fully an insane person, borderline socially impaired in her level of jealously towards anyone who so much as speaks to Yuki, and not once but twice imprisons him against his will. And yet he always comes back, never because he really cares about her or fully trusts her but because Yuki needs Yuno to stay alive. Now, I'm sure if I needed someone to never be more than five feet from me in order to remain with all my body parts, I would probably have to at some point form an emotional bond with them and ultimately may fall in love. But if said person proves to be a hazard to me just as much as any of the possible assailants, than forget protection. And while if she did prove to in the end help more than hinder, than I may have considered them at least tolerable. But in the end ***spoilers*** Yuno attempts to kill Yuki anyway. And what does he do after that? Sacrifices himself in order for her, the true her, to be get a better life, under the impression that second Yuno has a different, more caring nature than the first one who killed her own self. ***spoilers end*** Now, that's a textbook example of a dependent relationship: Assuming that if you stick around for a person, you can fix them and that they have a different side to them that you just have to pull out. Spoiler alert in a different manner: This is an untruth. Life doesn’t work like that. If a person is negatively impacting your life and health, you leave them Yuki. The point is though that Yuki is just as manipulative of Yuno as she is of him, calling her his girlfriend whenever she needs him to kill someone for him / not kill someone for him, and that manipulation leads him to even mixing up needing a person to stay with you for protection as needing this person to stay around because you love them. It’s possible that Yuki even convinces himself he loves her as a survival strategy, but that treading in deeper water than this show deserves. In total, their relationship is wholly unhealthy and manipulative, and the obsession for Redail's happier ending between the two is sickening nearly.


Final notes: What is this yandere obsession? What? Someone explain it to me. Yes I can understand its significance in School Days because it came out of practically nowhere, but why is Yuno dubbed Yandere Queen? Everyone knew she was mentally unstable and that one of them was going to have to die, so it’s not exactly like that end came out of left field, or any such killings for that matter. Really the show is set up for her to be a yandere, and yet no one comments on shows like Btooom! where the characters there kill for love as well, in equally insane situations. I guess there is some insanity threshold to classify as yandere? I enjoy its 'surprise' qualities, except in Future Diary, it truly was no surprise.


The ending. Honestly, it has some crazy cool twists and build-ups, or at least, twists and build ups that WOULD HAVE been really crazy and cool, if the show wasn’t already burdened with dues ex to the stars and back, to the point nothing could have really come across as a surprise. And then the fact that it took like three whole episodes the complete that ending arc, dragging it on and on for far too long. The ending is one I would have loved had it been nearly any other show, because it shows real thought for the creators and as I said it was just plain cool and at least mildly original. But in the case of Future Diary, it was way too late to be cool any more. It also proved why the whole time all the other Diary users were so wary of Yuno, except how could any of them known that about her if they were not already god? Yet another thing that comes across and incredibly heavy-handed by the creators.


To summarize, Mirai Nikki is one of those shows that is so bad that it's good. But not good in a way that we all learn from it; no, instead Future Diary is put upon some sort of pedestal the community loves to support for those 'gritty, edgy' shows. But the only thing Future Diary has going for it is the fact that it pulls us in with a stellar idea, and then keeps us around by being shocking and ridiculous just for the hell of it. The fact that this is a popular anime is almost insulting to the community at large, up there with a Human Centipede level grossness that is its own selling factor, but the fact we're all cool with that is hard to digest. I dont want to say that people cant like whatever they want, as for much as I detest Sword Art Online, Im still on good terms with people who love it to death. But this, I would love to see someone defend it's legitimacy as a moving art form, beyond pure 'entertainment' value of seeing the mentally deranged self-destruct everything and everyone around them.

This is my first ever review on this site! Not a great anime to debut though...
I'm a positive person so I'll begin with what I liked.
The art is decent. There are scenes where you can see some weirdness but on the whole, it's quite good. It's animated well with some really good high frame rate scenes in the last few episodes. Most of the cel-shading is also pretty good and the character of Deus ex Machina is really cool to look at.
The music is also quite good though there are many times where they just want to bash you over the head with the "sadness"or the "loneliness" or the "friends-are-so-damn-important-so-even-if-you-die-we-will-remember-you" aspects and the music here just feels cheesy. But it's a decent score but nothing noteworthy.


Now the bad. And there is a LOT of bad.


Firstly, the goddamned story. What. The. FUCK.

The first episode blew me away with the sheer potential this anime possesses and the awesome concept of precognition through something as lowly as a diary. The character of Deus, the stalker Yuno, the meek and reserved Yukki, all were an excellent recipe for a show that could very well turn into and excellent sequence of chases, mind-bending twists and one-upmanship over the other contestants and a true showcase of a potentially epic battle of wits. 


Then everything slowly but surely crumbles as meaningless plot twists, useless characters, utterly unbelievable reactions and a pathetic protagonist are mixed and it ends with such an idiotic climax that I was just glad to be over with the whole damn thing. The true twist I really didn't see coming but at that point I was pretty much at my zenith of boredom leading to my reaction being just an "oh, that happened" instead of "OH MY FUCKING GOD WHAAAT".


The diaries are incredibly idiotic and never really used as how we'd imagined. Are they used to achieve the owner's ends and successfully trick the others? Not really. What actually kills them is mostly a combination of incredibly dumb luck, bullets, knives etc. It's not the brains and the combination of will and wit that wins, but the brawn impeded by brainlessness. The formula is usually, somehow get to the opponent using the diary, face off with brawn, some touchy-feely shit and something happens to the opponent. IF it was done the first time to build the dumbass protagonist in the first few matches it would have been fine. BUT... this brings me to my next point which is - 


These characters SUCK. Holy crap, they drove me so goddamned MAD.

What the FUCK was with Yukki? I mean, this dude NEVER EVER wants to grow up from his obvious weaknesses, his delusions, his inferiority complex, NOTHING. He's been given one of the most powerful weapons and elevated to a god among men with only a handful more who share the dias. Does he take this as an opportunity to grow as a person, learn to fend for himself and kick-ass? NOPE NOT HAPPENING. Forget kicking ass, this guy can barely defend or even think by himself. He continues to be a child till the very end, repeatedly tricked by Yuno into loving her and almost never makes a conscious decision of his own.

And Yuno? She was as 2D a character as they come with her decidedly one-point agenda upto the very end. You may try and excuse her constant pining as being that of the yandere character she's supposed to be but this only leads to some VERY stupid decisions and some overtly protective/murderous actions. She NEVER thinks for herself or plans for the future. We are shown that she's awesome with bursts of amazing deduction but these are so unbelievable and interspersed with pure stupidity that we just call bullshit on them after the first few episodes.

The other contestants are invariably psychopaths that should never have been selected for this position in the first place, forcing us to somehow hope Yukiteru gets the spot in the end (which was an eventuality from the start) so these psychotic fucks don't get the opportunity. Also one of the contestants being allowed in the game was highly suspect given his role and I'll never believe he would be allowed to participate.

The other characters are equally, if not worse, criminally underdeveloped or utterly useless. I see no point in Kousuke or Mao ever being a "major" characters. Akise Aru was also never really fleshed out. Hinata was purely a fan service character.


But ani, ani, what about romance, fan service, blood and gore and wholesome yandere fun? LOL seriously? If any of these elements were present in decent amounts to tone down the seriousness of the plot the I wouldn't have been this harsh on the anime. Unfortunately, the fan service is sparse, the romance is irritating and the gore is barely there. You get spouts and gushes of blood, a couple of chopped heads, some missing limbs but that's it. Having seen Elfen Lied, this is all very tame and barely stimulating.


A pointless and meandering story, moronic characters and some truly awful pacing with random bits of humour or sentiment suddenly destroying the previous mood wreck a concept with vast potential which let me down considerably. I'm not looking back at this time wasted with any fondness.

DISCLAIMER: i am going to try to keep this spoiler free but most points i want to make take place in the final few episodes so please be aware that there may be slight spoilers.
STORY
Apart from the ending in my opinion Mirai nikki has one of the best stories ive seen in a long time in a anime.
Essentially the plot is based around a survival game where 12 individuals are given unique diaries that aside from their unique traits essentially can predict the future.
However this future can be altered by the actions of any living diary holder.
The point of this survival game is tobe thelast man/woman standing and the winner will succeed the current god and become a god themself.


the best way to describe it is a 12 man battle royale version of Deathnote.


as you can imagine this is a very smart show and the confrontations are very well done and is full of many subplots.


Also one thing i enjoyed is the fact that even though Yuki and Yuno are the main characters everyone else is given enough spotlight that it can feel like there is no real protaganist at times and you will probaly feel for all the characters at some point.


now i mentioned i didnt like the ending and that is because unlike the rest of the show which is well paced and while complicated it wasnt overly complicated.........yea the ending does the opposite of that.


Trying to avoid spoilers i wont go into detail but they pull a huge amount of plot twists and overly complicated explanations that while they do explain everything leaving nothing unanswered (as far as i know) its done in such a way that the viewer is overrun with so much information that its hard to keep track of whats going on.


honestly the ending isnt horrible its just the way its presented oh and the fact that it basicly turns into a super powered naruto-esque fight sequence.



ART AND SOUND



as far as the art and sound go nothing really stands out apart from the openings.

The openings are done great but everything else isnt great but then again its not horrible either so there really isnt much to say about them.


The character designs are good but not anything we havent really seen before.



CHARACTER



as i said before the main characters are yuno and yuki but everyone else could just as easily be main character potential.

Almost everyone has a rich and fleshed out backstory and is relatable in one way or another.


Number 4 wants to maintain justice

Number 12 wants to make the city be remembered through the ages and number 8 just wants to take care of her family.


Out of all the characters the two that got the most development however is uryuu (number 8) and yuki (number 1)

uryuu goes from this cold and ruthless terrorist to this almost mentor character, while yuki.........well yuki suffers from shinji hikari syndrome.

he starts off as a giant crybaby who cant do anything on his own but slowly (emphasis on slowly) becomes capable of taking care of himself by the end of the series.


Then you have yuno......i know im gonna get alot of hate for this but........yuno kinda sucks.

let me explain.

look im a big fan of yandere characters so i tried to like yuno the poster child for yandere but she is just too much.

most yandere have a single trigger that shifts them into yandere mode and is normal the rest of the time.

Not yuno sadly.

She is yandere 90% of the time however i will give this a little bit of room to work with due to the main twist at the ending making it somewhat understandable.

my main issue is that she has no development she is just a yandere for the sake of being a yandere.

even for yandere fans like myself there really are no redeeming qualities for her aside from the fact that she can be cute.



ENJOYMENT


despite the shows faults i still enjoyed it because it was so well written and my faults with the ending can be overlooked because its a good ending just felt kinda rushed and not needed.

i still recommend it just be kinda open minded with the ending.

In my honest opinion, Mirai Nikki is almost perfect.
It has just the right balance of action, suspence, drama, romance and of course violence.
Gasai Yuno, the female "protagonist" if you could call her that, is easily my favourite character in any show ever. The story is full of suspense and plot twist that I could some people disliking however I love it.
The sound track is brilliant from the First opening, to the epic moment songs, to the second closing song.
Most of the time the animation is fantastic, however at certain times it lacked a certain something, but that should not detract from your enjoyment.
If there wereany show I could recommend any show more, I have not seen it yet, I urge you to at least give Mirai Nikki a try, and with an english dub coming soon there is no reason why you shouldn't try it.

Mirai Nikki, where do i begin? One of my favorite animes.  Its a great story and you can´t wait for the next episode. If you got a weak heart or are Afraid of blood i woulden´t recomend this serie for you, if you are like me and a bit twisted GZ you just found a great anime
Beside from the blood and violence i realy like when you get to know the characters. The mindblowns are real and the plots are realy smart. This may sound a bit mean but if you are stupied this anime will be a bit hard for you to fallow.
OverallGreat anime that i still enjoy to watch

I'm just going to keep this short and lazy.
Amazing concept, very poor execution. Unlikable characters, very little plot consistency, writing sometimes falls to baffling levels of terrible.
However, if every part of Mirai Nikki was as good as the beginning and the ending, it could have been great. Sure, some things didn't quite click, but the plot came together at least somewhat cohesively.
Too bad the OVA screwed it up completely

Mirai Nikki, when i first heard of this show i expected it to be very similar to Eden of the East, and thus i expected to have a boring plot that i had seen before.
How wrong I was! Mirai nikki keeps you on the edge of your seat constantly, it has an outstanding plot that takes you on a roller-coaster of a ride. The emotion between the characters is a masterpiece, and in general it was very well thought out. Every week i have been anticipating the next episode, staying up late just to watch it. Its kept me hooked and interested all the way,and now that its nearly at an end im rather sad that such a great show is going to end. But by jove im enjoying all the loose ends they are tying up, i just hope they don't leave any sort of gaps in the story that leaves you guessing.\n
I don't foresee a second series, and to be honest that is a good thing. This show will end perfectly at the 26th episode, and you will most likely feel very fulfilled.\n\n
The only thing that prevents me from giving it an overall 10 is the gore, im not a great fan of it. But im sure most others out there enjoy it, so im just being a little bias there.

This is my first review so no hating, ok? :3 Well a little criticism is fine, but make it constructive.
I've watched many anime, but of all, I found Mirai Nikki the most thrilling. The plot is similar to the Hunger Games, but instead its set in a different time period and darker. The main character here is Amano Yukiteru, a plain student who doesn't like to stand out much, but ends up being caught up in the bloody game, and is one of the few diary owners who are still sane.
Story: 9/10
The plot, like I said, is the same as the Hunger Games, a classicelimination battle royale plot. The story isn't incredibly fast paced, But there is the big twist that comes along the way. Sure, it may be a game where everyone has to kill each other, but this is also where it splits from Hunger Games. Its not what you think at first. Along the anime, the more diary owners are killed, the more the plot dives deeper into the past life of Yuno, a psychotic but sweet girl who is obsessed with Yukiteru (also known as yandere). The reason why I gave the story a 9/10, though, is because this anime breaks the fourth wall a bit too much, giving some pathetic characters a giant edge over something that normally wouldn't be possible.


Art: 10/10

What can I say? Amazing art. It actually compliments the thrill and psychology in this anime. The art is clear and the character emotions and gestures are shown beautifully.


Sound: 10/10

Music is good, shows the aura of the anime and goes along with the anime. Yousei Teikoku is my favourite band since their music creates the best feel for this anime. Dead End (second opening) actually shows what happens in the anime if you look at the lyrics. Voice acting is fantastic, especially when acting out as the personality of the characters.


Character: 10/10

This is what got me so excited about Mirai Nikki. Yuki's personality is a wimp who before, does not want anything to do with the game, due to the horrors he had witnessed at the beginning. The fact that this anime has a pathetic and weak main character is what makes this anime better, and the fact that later in the anime he ends up putting a proud and confident act is what pushes it better. The side characters are also well developed and there are reasons concerning their actions. Yuno Gasai, the female lead character, is also the main selling point of the anime. Her back story is not as tragic as the Sixth, yet her personality was the result of what happened when she was small. Shes one of the best yanderes I've ever seen, as one moment shes cute and innocent, the next moment she does something completely unpredictable and insane.


Enjoyment: 10/10

I loved this anime. The thrill of it was what made me watch it without dropping it. Ever since I watched the first episode, I would wonder what happened in the next episode and would want to watch it in school secretly. Mirai Nikki is an anime that was so unexpected that sometimes I would try to predict what would happen next and then it would completely surprise me.


Overall: 9/10

If you liked Higurashi and Chaos;Head, then I think it would be good giving Mirai Nikki a shot. Sure, not as much horror as Higurashi, but the dark effects and psychological scenes make up for it.

Mirai Nikki has a great survival game premise.  The main characters try to kill the other players or avoid being killed by using their diaries to see into the future.  Fortunately this idea never strays off course and we are left with a fun beginning to end watch.  As the game nears the end, we bite into a few treats that were only hinted at before.  The bloody road along with the sometimes irritating romance, concluded with a most satisfactory ending that made the journey all worth it.  From my understanding, the anime followed the manga pretty well, but inthe end, they left out a few pages that would of been nice to see.  Maybe these few pages would of been confusing but once read, they really make the ending that much sweeter.


Great animation.  The characters and everything in the Nikki world were detailed and brought to life.  The fights were slick and easy to follow.  Nothing looked half-assed.  The fights were bloody and boy was there blood.  The one thing that bothered me about the fights though was when someone got seriously injured and blood was pouring out of the wound, the wound itself was censored.  So, in some cases during this R rated anime, censorship was used.  In reality, I can certainly see why censorship was used, being a shounen and all, but it's one of those points I have to include.  With all the blood and killing shown, censoring something like a knife in the gut seems preposterous.  It was not always, just a few times throughout.


I'll let the opening and endings alone.  They fit the bill but not everyone liked the heaviness of them.  As for the music in between, not much can be said other than it also fit the moments.  When love was in the air, you better believe love music was in the air.  A serious fight brought on serious fighting music.  In no way was the music lacking.


Ah yes, the characters.  Much can be said about the characters.  I'll start by saying Yukki made the beginning of the anime hell.  The angst was almost unbearable.  For like 17 episodes, he refused to grow a pair. Yuno on the other hand, made the beginning worthwhile with her obsessive psychotic love for Yuki.  Nothing can stop her from protecting Yukki.  All the while nothing can stop Yukki from crying as Yuno fights for him.  Alas, don't be put off, the ending is well worth it.  Watching Yukki develop may be a hair pulling experience, but he matures into the guy we wished for in episode one.  Being a survival game, we not only have our main guys, but the anime takes a step back sometimes to explore the other players realities.  This step is a breathe of fresh air from the angst and love that dwells in each episode. 


Overall I can't stress enough that this anime should be given a chance. At least till like episode 17.  Even before that though it's a great watch.  The premise alone makes the wait for developments interesting.  The fighting and epic background music both succeed in setting the right mood and right pace.  The gore adds to that but usually when there's gore, there's Yukki crying somewhere; where there's Yukki, there's Yuno.  Like I said, persevere, it's character development.  The other players are all pretty great characters and though Yukki and Yuno can be hard to watch sometimes, when the plots a movin', everything becomes exciting.  So give it a chance, maybe you'll see that it was actually a pretty great anime.

Diaries that can predict the future in vastly different ways, a winner takes all survival game, 12 psychopaths competing for the role of god, and a stalker girl that refuses to leave the main character alone. These are the  main themes of Mirai Nikki, and these are also both the show's greatest strengths, and it's greatest weaknesses.
Yukiteru Amano is a quiet, 14 year old middle school student who borders on being anti-social. One day, he finds out that the journal he keeps on his cell phone is already filled in for the day, predicting the events that happen around him. He also comes tofind out though that Deus, the being he thought was his imaginery friend, is actually god, and that he has been thrown into a last man standing survival game in which the winner claims the title of the new god. Couple that with the fact that a crazy, murderous stalker who also happens to be a player has fallen in love with him, and you have a general idea of the premise of Mirai Nikki.



Story

The storyline in Mirai Nikki is one of the best aspects of the show. If you couldn't tell from the description above, Mirai Nikki has a setup that just pulls you in, offering a great premise to get you excited about the events to come. That said, it needs to be understood that this survival game isn't one along the lines of say "Eden of the East", where the game is more of a backdrop for a though provoking story. Mirai Nikki's survival game is kill or be killed, no exceptions. The show prefers to just let cool things happen even if they aren't properly explained, which is a blessing and a curse.


On the one hand, it makes for some truly enjoyable moments, but it does often leave you with the impression that the show just doesn't care if the events make sense, leaving you with the impression it was just rushed or downright ignored. But again, if your willing to just raise your suspension of disbelief and turn your brain off while your watching it, there is a lot of action and cool moments to justfiy watching.


As far as pacing goes, it moves at a very nice rate, keeping things interesting and ensuring that it never takes to long on one certain thing, keeping you entertained in the process. The ending is also surprisingly interesting, being a bit complex and a bit difficult to wrap your head around at first, but it is quite clever once you figure it out and makes the last 3-4 episodes some of the most enjoyable in the series. That said, you should probably check the last chapter of the manga after finishing the show, as their are about 10 pages or so that were unanimated, and it's definitely worth seeing them as they clear up a few questions.


Ultimatley, the story is very enjoyable with a few twists and turns throughout it to keep you engaged. I doens't always take the time it should to explain things to the viewer but with the fast pace and cool moments you'll hardly have time to notice. Ultimately though, the story is brought down the most by it's characters.



Characters

I'll put it bluntly, the characters are probably the worst thing about Mirai Nikki. For a show revolving around 12 people vying for the role of god, the characters must be interesting and engaging in order for the seutp to work. Thankfully, not all the characters are bad. As most of the characters have some form of psychological problem, some of them truly are interesting. Such as a blind man who dresses up like a power ranger acting as an agent of justice, a little boy whose parents fight, and a terrorist who might not be as bad as she first seems to be. The sad thing is, not all the characters are that good, and most of the tones that are good are quickly killed off and never brought up again.


It's not that all the other characters are bad per se, it's just that despite the show trying to gibe them interesting backstories and trying to make you care, most just come off as boring and you never really care about them. For a show all about a game in which only one will survive, having likeable, interesting characters is a necessity, but Mirai Nikki fails to deliver on this in all but a few cases.


Also important in defining the characters are each of their future diaries. Each player in the survival game had a diary they keep, and each one fills them in on future events in various different ways. Some are simple, such as telling the user what events happen around him, or another that details what will happen to someone the user is close too. Some of these future diaries get a bit bizarre though, and there's one later in the show that allows other future diaries to be made from it. It's an interesting concept, but it's never explained exactly how this can work, and the show just doesn't seem to care that it makes no sense.


Despite a few leaps in logic such as that though, the future diaries are a key part of Mirai Nikki, and it's always interesting to find out what diary a certain person has, and how it can be used to help them kill the other players.


The worst offender as far as characters go is sadly the main man himself, Yukiteru. He whines, complains, and cries all to often, making him just a constant annoyance to the viewer. It's understandable for him to be afraid at first, after all, he's just been thrown into this crazy survival game and now has a crazy murderous woman following him around, but the problem is that he never grows throughout the show. He does have some moments of courageousness, but he never grows from them, despite the fact that after every one it seems like a great chance to develop his character.


There to pick up the slack though is Yuno, that crazy, murderous stalker I mentioned earlier. Yuno is probably the best character in the show, seeming sweet and innocent, and just when you think she's not so bad, something is revealed about her which takes you back to her true nature of being a crazy, murderous, psycho, and she is one of the few characters to have truly good development. Over the course of the show you will learn more and more about her, making you wonder what her true motives really are.



Art

There really isn't much to say about the art and animation in this show. It's certainly not bad or anything, but it's nothing to write home about either. The colors look nice and the character designs are alright, nothing spectacular though. You can tell some shortcuts were taken at certain points, but the animation does get a noticeable bump near the end of the series as most shows do, so it's not so bad. All in all the art in Mirai Nikki is alright, it gets the job done but doens't break any good ground. There is some nicely animated action sequences, so I'll give it that.


Sound

As with the animation, the sound is so-so. All the background music sets the mood well, and there are a few stand out tracks, but it's not the best soundtrack I've heard. The openings and endings though I though were quite nice, most of them giving some sort of look at the 12 players in the survival game, and they set the mood of the show well.



Enjoyment

In terms of pure enjoyment, Mirai Nikki may be one of the most purely enjoyable anime I've seen. It's not deep or thought provoking, but it is a lot of fun to watch and downright entertaining. There are just so many memorable moments in this show that are either really cool, "epic", or even a few touching ones. Even if you don't like a lot of things about the show, you'll be hard pressed not to find a multiple moments in the show that bring a smile to your face, as there are quite an abundance of them, particuarly when the show really gets going in it's second half.



Overall

All in all, how much you like Mirai Nikki will be determined by how willing you are to overlook a few cases of things going unexplained and a few plot holes for the sake of high adrenaline, "awesome" moments. If your like me than you'll be able to look past some of those flaws and just enjoy it for what it is, which is basically just a fast paced battle royal featuring a cast of psychopaths using diaries that can predict the future to kill each other.A few of these characters being very well done, where as some fall very short.


Either way, as long as you are willing to look past these faults, Mirai Nikki is a very enjoyable expirence with a story that is surprsisngly good and only bogged down by a lack of great characters. I would reccomend this show to anyone who likes a show that doesn't force them to think to hard, and just gives them something enjoyable, adrenaline packed, and with a few twists and turns throughout.


If the characters had been better than I would have probably given this show a 9, but as they are one of the most important parts of the show and they just aren't as good as they need to be, I had to drop my overall score to an 8.

I want to say... 'Jack of all genres, master of none.'
What. The. Eff.
I'll keep this review short and (not-so) sweet.
I'll start with the positive though. The concept is clever and although elements of it have been done before, I feel it did bring something new-ish to the table. I didn't pick the twist until it was almost staring me in the face, but I liked the fact that even though the clues were there, it wasn't bang-on obvious. I felt I had to endure the first 18 episodes to get to the good stuff though.
Animation and sound is solid too.
Ok, so if you like yourcharacters at the opposite ends of the emotional spectrum, then this is for you. And the females, oh the females in this were portrayed horribly. There was hardly any normality. It was either back the psychos or the tragics. Not a fan at all of how they were shown and the men weren't that crash-hot either. The relationship between the two mains is also quite cringeworthy, right up until the last few episodes I reckon. Plus if I have to hear 'Pookie' again, I'll scream.\n\n
Unfortunately I think the other main drawback for this series was that it tried too hard to fit a bit of everything in. Romance, comedy, both yaoi and yuri connotations, horror, drama, action, supernatural... It's too much for one series. However, when the action gets going (especially when they pit their diary's unique abilities against each other) it becomes pretty decent to watch.\n\n
So for concept, animation and gore... give Mirai Nikki a go. But if you want characters, consistency and something solid to watch... find something else.\n

Marai Nikki is an effectively frightening, unrestrained, and twistedly dark addition to the psychological thriller anime genre featuring brutally fast paced action, fantastic character arcs, and an intense atmosphere guaranteed to satisfy anyone’s craving for horror.
Marai Nikki provides everything a horror anime fan could ever want including a demented and dark story line, some insane visuals, and tons of gore, which delivers a plethora of intensity from start to finish.  One of the objectives of an exploitation thriller is to always pack in a ton of insanity and haunting visuals to shock or disturb the audience into feeling uneasy consistently throughout each episode.Marai Nikki delivers on that front.  From the beginning it does not hold back immediately thrusting our protagonist Yuki into the horrifying setting where the goal is to use future diaries to kill others in a game to claim God’s throne.  This hook featuring Yuno’s introduction and some quality world building creates massive amounts of energy and anticipation.  The story itself may be nothing new in today's current times, but is elevated in this instance by the over the top intensity in this show that other survival game thrillers generally shy away from.  Around every turn are frequently haunting visuals and a sense of urgency that is sure to keep you on the edge of your seat (so binge syndrome is a possibility with this one).  Another reason this show is so infamously insane is due to its demented and depressing tone coupled with many memorable twists and turns.  These elements are well executed and well-paced as they fit into the story line perfectly and are never aggrandized.  Nothing is ever as it seems throughout the anime which plays into the overall fun the series has to offer.  Characters who you think are trustworthy may turn out to be demented and characters that are edgy may tend to be more morally grounded then one would think.  The anime also recognizes its purpose as an over the top brutal exploitation thriller and perceptibly avoids over stylization and dramatization allowing for the horror elements to shine.  These themes and tones palpably come together to create an unpredictable, twisted, and mental experience. 


One of the most underrated and less recognized aspects of Marai Nikki is its cast of characters and their brilliantly constructed character arcs.  The main character arcs in this anime focus on Yuno and Yuki’s relationship throughout much of the show (and unless you live under a rock you know everything about that already).  Yuno’s personality of course drives many of the changes we see in Yuki throughout most episodes.  However, I found the most interesting character development in the show to revolve around the side cast.  Much of the time we see many characters commit some of the most horrific acts of evil you could ever imagine.  However, by the end of the story many of these characters become strangely identifiable and even likable to the point where we perceive them as protagonists, which is extremely strange and very interesting.  Creating arcs in which a character can commit the most terrible crimes against humanity and then showing them as someone who you should identify with is not an easy feat and rarely done well if at all.  These spectacularly well-constructed character arcs showcase the writer’s abilities to create many memorable twists and turns but are also relevant to the themes of the show as identifying with these characters despite their atrocities adds to the unsettling tones throughout the show.  The cast is also well balanced in terms of their abilities and personalities.  We have character battles between children, brute type brawlers, strategists, and downright demented psychopaths which keeps the action and suspense diverse throughout the anime.    


Lastly the anime’s atmosphere, animation and themes clearly exemplify how an anime does not have to be cleanly animated or overly detailed to have an impact.  The animation, soundtrack, and setting all focus on intense character expressions and action sequences throughout the show.  This allows for the audience to focus on the weight of each movement during these sequences along with the terror on the faces of the characters rather than be distracted by overly detailed animation.  The soundtrack featuring Yousei Teikoku is also a nice touch and successfully adds a lot of excitement to each episode.  


All of this being said this show is not a complete masterpiece.  It could benefit from having Yuki’s character arc appear earlier in the show as in the beginning he is overly obnoxious at times.  Another point to consider is at its core this is a horror slasher anime so it is of course lacking in depth or meaning.  However, while it is certainly not for the faint of heart Marai Nikki will always be remembered as one of the greats in the horror/psychological anime realm and a must watch for any fan of the genre.

So that you know where I'm coming from I'm not a really big fan of this show.I just felt like I should write a review so that I can make sense to myself and others as to why I gave this a decent rating despite all the problems with it. Before you read any further it'd be good if you knew that this review should not spoil the story any more than the MAL synopsis has.. The best thing about the anime is it's story progression (not the story itself which had a lot of problems for me). I know special attention was given tokeeping the suspense because of it's ability to make going from one episode to another less of a chore.The feeling I got was not that I HAD to check the next episode so that I could eventually find out if I wasted my time even starting the show; instead I felt like I had to know what happened next almost every episode.Besides that there were a lot of problems with this anime like "why did Yuno care so much about Yuki, that she'd do what she did?", the unnecessary moments where the female characters were made into fan service despite the good quality of the story which will keep people interested anyways.I think the score in relation to art should be low if they couldn't do any better than that, and for the character development to take the turn it did was a bad choice as well so even though I love how they built up the story I can't say it was as good as I'd like it to have been.

Found Mirai Nikki by typing "best anime 2012" into google and clicking the first link. One of the best decisions ever made! Mirai Nikki is a thriller in which the characters play their role until the end. 12 characters gain the power to see the future by Deus Ex (the God of Time and Space) through use of their individual diaries. Each diary has its unique advantage as well as its own disadvantage that helps the character survive (or die). The story line isn't why people should watch this Anime. Yuno - the main female plays the best Yandere I have ever seen. Obsessed withthe main Male lead -Yuuki, Yuno protects him until the very end. Yuno is beautiful, smart, and resourceful but when watchers learn what she is really capable of its both scary and fascinating. If you read the Manga then you know that this anime also has a surprise twist at the end.

This is my first review so I'm sorry if I get this wrong xD
Mirai Nikki, or, Future diary (however you prefer) Is straight up amazing, I absolutely loved it! It is one of those Unique anime's that you will rarely find, but when you do, you'll have so many urge's to watch it forever!
Story: The story for Mirai Nikki is amazing, For a survival genre of anime, I'm really impressed with the originality that has been set, It has so many twists and turns that will leave you clueless, bombshells that will make your jaw drop & Literally the most unique ending I have EVERseen! It will have you in tears, begging for more!

Overall I rate the story a 10/10 Easily, It is so amazing so It deserves nothing less!


Art: The art for Mirai Nikki was very well done, you get the nice motion, modern day feel with the new anime's while watching this, the Scenery is amazing as well, especially how well the atmospheric changes occur at the right moment, for instance, an emotional scene would have rain or snow.

There might be a few scene's that leave you a question or two, but it's really hard to notice and is usually just a distant face or an odd angle, Overall, I rate it an 8/10 :)


Sound: The soundtrack for Mirai Nikki is Outstanding, it encourages the experience of feeling like you're actually there! the combat music is one of a kind, it couldn't be better, however, it was the emotional soundtracks that really got me, the are honestly to good to explain, you'll have to watch it and see what I mean :P

Overall, I rate the sound a 9/10 (p.s there may be a few overused sound effects that you will hear in blogs & skits, but it really doesn't affect the experience)


Character: The character build in this anime is Flawless, they'll feel so real you'll start to believe they are! It astonishes me how well they developed each character, good or bad, giving them their own unique features that makes them grow into someone you'll be fascinated in! The dark past's and bright future's of everyone make the characters more likeable as well!

Overall, I rate the character's a 10/10 they couldn't have made it better


Enjoyment: I have said it before and I will say it again, I LOVED Mirai Nikki, with each episode bringing a new  adventure to the table you'll never be sitting there in boredom! every episode will leave you begging for more because it is so addictive, Overall, I rate the Enjoyment a 9/10 (The only reason why it isn't a 10 is because there is such an emotional part that will make you break down and cry like a baby)


My final rating is a 9/10! It is absolutely outstanding and is definitely a must watch! I tried to make sure I didn't reveal any spoilers whilst also trying to make it sound approachable, so sorry if this wasn't to helpful :P

Once again this is my first review, so don't be to harsh! XD

-Earlysmasher
